turns.speaker: CARLSON
turns.text: No, sir.  It will never happen again.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Here!  This cauliflower is useless to me.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: He has a big mouth.  Yes!  It seems to me I did read something about that incident as a student.  But you have to remember that a worm -- with very few exceptions -- is not a human being.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Bring me some surgical gauze, a little tape and some disinfectant.

turns.speaker: CARLSON
turns.text: Yes, sir.  Do you want the other cauliflower?

turns.speaker: CORNELIUS WALDMAN
turns.text: Herr Falkstein!  Did you inform Frederick Frankenstein of this assembly and all the particulars of the time and place?

turns.speaker: HERR FALKSTEIN
turns.text: But I received a cable only this morning, saying that he could not come.

turns.speaker: CORNELIUS WALDMAN
turns.text: Was he aware of the importance of this occasion?

turns.speaker: HERR FALKSTEIN
turns.text: Yes, sir, he was.  But he said he was obligated to lecture at Johns Hopkins University.

turns.speaker: CORNELIUS WALDMAN
turns.text: What lecture could be more important than the will of Baron Beaufort Frankenstein?

turns.speaker: HERR FALKSTEIN
turns.text: 'Functional areas of the cerebrum in relation to the skull.'

turns.speaker: CORNELIUS WALDMAN
turns.text: Herr Falkstein! You have your instructions!

turns.speaker: CORNELIUS WALDMAN
turns.text: I have taken an oath that each letter of this testament shall be executed...and by God, it shall be done!

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: What in God's name are you doing?

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: All right then... seven's always been my lucky number.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Probably just some nearby cottage. Nothing to worry about.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Did you see?...I put a special hamper in the bathroom just for your shirts.  the other one is just for socks and poo-poo undies.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: So this is what it's like to be completely happy!

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Call me from New York before you leave??

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Oh, darling -- I'll count the hours that you're away.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Mother's going to help me with the invitations.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: I hope you like large weddings.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: I've trimmed the list to only our very closest friends...but it still comes to three thousand.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Does that mean you love me?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: You bet your boots it does.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Love you! ...Well, why don't we turn in?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: I mean, it's been a long day. I'm sure you must be as tired as I am.  Oh!  These are my assistants:  Inga and Ayegor.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Yes.  I am a bit tired, after all.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Give me a hand with these, will you, Ayegor?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Yes, he's a little bit... tilted. Harmless, though.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Are you suggesting I call him master???

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: No, of course not.  I just meant...

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Poor Delbruck!  There must be some way to reach him -- to control that body.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: But there's a genius inside that body -- crying out for love and understanding and normal human relationships.  I just have to find some way to re-establish his communications system.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: But you can't do that at night. And even if you could -- it would cost a fortune.  Come to bed, darling.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Oh, Delbruck, Delbruck.  Was will dien tachlas von Dir?

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: You've done everything that's humanly possible, Frederick.  Oh, darling, I'm so worried about you -- you need rest.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Of course I am.  Now come along like a good boy.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Is your room just down the hall? ... in case I get frightened during the night?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Yes, but... I thought, perhaps tonight, under the circumstances, I might... stay here with you.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Oh, darling!  Don't let's spoil everything.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: I don't want to spoil anything -- I just want to top it all off.

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Would you want me, now, like this, so soon before our wedding? ... So near we can almost touch it? Or wait a little while longer, when I can give myself without hesitation?... When I can be totally and unashamedly yours??

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Is it worth taking a chance?

turns.speaker: ELIZABETH
turns.text: Of course I am.  Now give me a kiss and say good night like my good boy.

turns.speaker: FRAU BLUCHER
turns.text: I hope you find this comfortable. This was Baron Victor's room.

turns.speaker: FRAU BLUCHER
turns.text: You'll fine the keys to all the rooms in my cas... all the rooms in your castle on this ring.  I'll leave it on the table here.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Does that include the key to the laboratory?

turns.speaker: FRAU BLUCHER
turns.text: No!  Dr. Frankenstein always kept that separate.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: There seem to be quite a few books.

turns.speaker: FRAU BLUCHER
turns.text: Yes, this was Victor's... the Baron's medical library.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: I see.  And where is my grandfather's private library?

turns.speaker: FRAU BLUCHER
turns.text: I don't know what you mean, sir.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: well, there was a public and a private library -- he said so in his will.  these books are all very general -- any doctor might have them in his study.

turns.speaker: FRAU BLUCHER
turns.text: This is the only library I know of.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Surely he kept his notes -- his private papers and records in some other place?

turns.speaker: FRAU BLUCHER
turns.text: I think you must be mistaken, sir.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: I don't think so.  Is my assistant taken care of?

turns.speaker: FRAU BLUCHER
turns.text: I put her in the guest room, just down the hall.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: What are you waiting around for, pickle puss?

turns.speaker: FRAU BLUCHER
turns.text: This wire came while you were gone. Your fiancee will be arriving any moment.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Elizabeth!?!  'Can't waits any longer.  Arrive in your arms at ten tonight.' Oh, God!  Not tonight.

turns.speaker: HERR FALKSTEIN
turns.text: Oh, at least, sir.  The land alone is worth a small fortune.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: But I can't just drop everything and leave.  I have responsibilities and obligations.

turns.speaker: HERR FALKSTEIN
turns.text: Do you have a hundred thousand of them, sir?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: How long will this whole thing take?

turns.speaker: HERR FALKSTEIN
turns.text: A week.  Ten days at most.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: I'll have to think it over.  It's not so easy just to pick up and...

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Well... if you're sure that I could accomplish everything in a week... I suppose I could manage it.

turns.speaker: HERR FALKSTEIN
turns.text: The old violinist -- you smashed his violin over your knee.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: All right then, I suppose I owe the family that much.  You'll have everything ready for me when I arrive?

turns.speaker: HERR FALKSTEIN
turns.text: One week -- I'll see to it, sir.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Well, thank you very much for all your trouble.

turns.speaker: HERR FALKSTEIN
turns.text: Not at all -- a great privilege, Doctor.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Saturday night then!  I'll take the train to New York and fly from there.

turns.speaker: HERR FALKSTEIN
turns.text: Saturday night, yes, sir.  Have a pleasant journey!

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: My name is pronounced Fron kon steen.

turns.speaker: MEDICAL STUDENT
turns.text: Oh!  I thought it was Dr. Frankenstein.

turns.speaker: MEDICAL STUDENT
turns.text: But aren't you the grandson of the famous Dr. Victor Frankenstein?... who performed such fascinating experiments in electricity and galvanism?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: That's true!  But my grandfather, Victor was, after all, what we might politely refer to as... a cuckoo!

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: I prefer, by far, to be remembered for my own small contributions to science.  Now if we can proceed to your questions.

turns.speaker: MEDICAL STUDENT
turns.text: Well sir... I'm not sure I understand the distinction between 'Reflexive' and 'Voluntary' nerve impulses.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Very good!  Since our lab work today is a demonstration of just that distinction... why don't we proceed?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: In conclusion... it should be noted that more than common injury to the nerve roots is always serious, because... once a nerve fibber is severed... there is no way to regenerate life back into it.  Are there any more questions before we leave?

turns.speaker: MEDICAL STUDENT
turns.text: Isn't it true that Darwin preserved a piece of vermicelli in a glass case until, by some extraordinary means, it actually began to move with voluntary motion?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Are you speaking of the worm, or ... the spaghetti.

turns.speaker: MEDICAL STUDENT
turns.text: But wasn't that the whole basis of your grandfathers work, sir...? the re-animation of component parts?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: My father was a sick man.

turns.speaker: MEDICAL STUDENT
turns.text: But aren't you the least bit curious about it, Doctor?  Doesn't the secret of life hold any intrigue for you?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: You are talking about the gibberish ravings of a lunatic mind.

turns.speaker: MEDICAL STUDENT
turns.text: Yes, but, sir... if it could be accomplished, wouldn't that eliminate disease from the human frame and render man invulnerable to any but a violent death?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: How old are you, young man?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Nineteen!  My dear young man... once the human organism has ceased to function, nature has deemed that creature to be dead.

turns.speaker: MEDICAL STUDENT
turns.text: But look at what's been done with hearts and kidneys!

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Hearts and kidneys are Tinker Toys! I'm talking about the Central Nervous System.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: I am a scientist...!  not a philosopher.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: You have more chance of re-animating this knife than you have of mending a broken nervous system,

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: My grandfather's work was Doo-Doo! Dead is Dead!  There's only one thing I am interested in... and that is the preservation of LIFE!

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: No, it's pronounced Fron kon steen.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: And do you also say Fro dereck?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Why isn't it Frodereck Fronkon steen?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: But they told me it was Ee gor.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Well, they were wrong then, weren't they?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: You were sent by Herr Falkstein, weren't you?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Yes, that's right.  My grandfather and your grandfather used to pal around together.  You and I should have a lot of laughs.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: This is Inga.  They thought you might need an assistant temporarily.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Incidentally -- I don't mean to embarrass you in any way, but I'm a rather brilliant surgeon.  Perhaps I can help you with that hump.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Why are you talking like that?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Suit yourself...I'm easy.  Better watch out for the wockers.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Go ahead, play dumb!  You'll lose your sockers and then be fockers.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: I wonder what's got into them?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: I got frightened all alone upstairs, so I came down here.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Did you hear that strange music?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Did you hear that strange music??

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Did you hear that strange music?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: It seems that way.  You didn't hear any music at all?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: You didn't hear... nothing! Aren't there any lights in this place?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Two switches over there, but I wasn't going to be the first.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Did you see anyone else down here?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: No, but when I first came in, there was a light coming from behind that steel door.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: It is!  This was my grandfather's private library.  Look at this!

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Funny it should just be lying out here on the table.  I wonder what kind of dribble this is?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Yes, I think we could all use a good laugh.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Very little decay.  With this magnificent specimen for a body, all we need now is an equally magnificent brain.  You know what to do!

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: I have a pretty good idea.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Do you have the name I wrote down?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Was he any good???  He was the finest natural philosopher, internal medicine diagnostician and chemical therapist of this century.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Can you imagine that brain in this body?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: I'm getting excited just thinking about it.  What if he's not there?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: He only died two weeks ago -- I'm sure they'll still have him. Hurry now.  I'll prepare the body.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: It's always been one of my favorite names.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: You're sure you know what you're doing?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Yes!  It's all written down in the notes.  Tie off the kites and come down!

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Yes, master.  Just don't turn on any radios.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: You'd better hurry -- I think it's going to rain.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: The ancient masters promised impossibilities and performed nothing.  We shall penetrate into the recesses of nature.  We shall ascend into the Heavens.  We shall command the thunders of Heaven, mimic the earthquake and even mock the invisible world with its own shadows.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Yes!  When I give the word -- throw the first switch!

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: It's not enough.  More!  More, do you hear me?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Wait till he sees the bill.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: But there must be a reason. This is science, not art.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: You mustn't take it so hard. Bucharest wasn't built in a day.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Don't try to cheer me up that way.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Well, I don't like to see you mope.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: You'll be getting me sad next.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: I'm sorry.  I don't mean to take out my frustration on you.  You've been a great help to me, and I've let you down.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: I'm not that sort you know.  I appreciate you feelings, but try to show them some other way.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: You're right!  Self-pity never got anyone anywhere.  Let's go back and finish our dinner.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Oh, do you like it?  I'm not partial to desserts, but this is excellent.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: To you!  You just made a 'yummy' sound, so I thought you liked the dessert.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: I didn't make a 'yummy' sound -- I just asked what it was.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: But you did -- I just heard it.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Better not get too close, master. This guy could kill you.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: I suppose you're right.  Inga! Prepare a sedative, just in case.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: It's trying to talk.  it wants us to take off the straps.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: But don't you see...the brain of Hans Delbruck is inside this grotesque hulk -- pleading with us.  I've got to untie it.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: careful, master -- you never can tell with these chaps.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Whew!  I'm glad that's over with.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: You're just supposed to repeat what you said.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: What's the point of my setup? It's not funny unless you repeat exactly what you said.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: I'm not trying to be funny.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Repeat it anyway -- it's a wonderful cue.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: ... Whew!  I'm glad that's over with.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: It seem to have stopped the big fellow in his tracks.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Ayegor!  Find out where that music is coming from as quietly and as blindingly fast as you can.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Someone was playing this in the music room.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: How do you know it was a 'he'?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: How do you know it was a 'she'?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Maybe...if you get here on time.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Come on, Froderick -- none of that.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: What d'ya mean "What monster?' You remember...the one we madein the basement.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: You don't understand, Master. The big fellow's broken in and kidnapped your fiancee.

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: He's carrying her off now through the woods.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: No!  The only hope now is to get him back here.  If I can just find a way to relieve the pressure on his cerebellum...

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: ... and equalize the imbalance in his cerebrospinal fluid...

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: I like your style, master.  How do we get him here?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Yes, master.  Are you sure you want to go through with it?

turns.speaker: IGOR
turns.text: Okay, boss!  But I hope you know what you're doing.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: I'm going to untie you -- can you understand that?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Yes, I'm going to set you free.  Is the sedative ready?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: It's alive.  It's -- moving! It's -- breathing!  It's -- standing!  What is your name?

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Diff'rent types who wear a day coat, pants with stripes and cutaway coat, perfect fits.........................

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Dressed up like a million dollar trouper Trying hard to look like Gary Cooper.

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: ...Su-per du-per. Come let's mix where Rock- e-fellers walk with sticks or 'um-ber- el-las' in their mitts.........................

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: For  God's sake -- go on!  Are you trying to make me look like a fool. Sing, you amateur!  Sing!!

turns.speaker: FREDDY
turns.text: Wait!  Stop!  Don't give them the satisfaction.  I know it's tough, but look at how far we've come! Are you going to throw it all away now??
